questions.question_text: A technician needs to connect to a network switch in a remote location. The technician wants to make sure the data passed over the wire is encrypted so it cannot be read by someone using a sniffer. Which of the following connection protocols should the technician use?

discussion.content: Got this on the test boys watch out

comments.content: Well D can tell you if you see them,unless you have a vpn that doesn't have split tunneling.

discussion.content:
[“the customer is unable to get to any wired network resources, shared drives, printers, or the Internet” – a DNS problem]
A – Ping – start by trying to ping the DNS server – this is clearly a DNS problem – see if you can connect to it
Not B - hwconfig.exe is known as Softing AG EDIC Hardware Installer and Configurator
Not C -- Nbtstat displays current TCP/IP connections and statistics. Why would you want to examine TCP/IP connections – you know there are none – “the customer is unable to get to any wired network resources”
Not D – Nslookup uses DNS to list IP addresses and/or DNS Names – won’t tell you if you can connect to them.

I take back my original answer C. If the ping command is successful, it means the network connection is working at least up to the point of the pinged device. If it fails, it indicates that there’s a network connectivity issue. So yea A.. ping
the answer is C...

This question is not set correctly, first how can you ping when you cannot get to any wired network resources, shared drives, printers, or the Internet. which means he cant able to see any one of them or not even connected. Guys so how can you ping when you need IP address of the other host. or you just ping ping and you get result from any where. you need to see any network which is available or diplay use ipconfig to display ip address of your network . im not sure what they really asking here.
NBstat has to do with statistics of tcp not network shares so PING is correct

Answer is B: 
NetBIOS is a non-routable OSI Session Layer 5 Protocol and a service that allows applications on computers to communicate with one another over a local area network (LAN)

comments.content: C i mean. NETBIOS COmmand

discussion.content: Ping is the correct answer here. Ipconfig only gives you the info where as ping will test you IP/TCP stack to troubleshoot it.
But doesn't ipconfig give you info but doesn't actually troubleshoot?
Yes, and then ping
I am pretty positive that the answer is ipconfig...

comments.content: IPCONFIG is not an option from the choices. The BEST answer is PING to figure out what you can or cannot actually reach on the network.

questions.question_text:
A customer's computer is powered on and working, but the customer is unable to get to any wired network resources, shared drives, printers, or the Internet.
Which of the following command-line tools should be used to troubleshoot this scenario?

A technician wants to deploy a solution to manage a computer remotely. The technician is not allowed to modify any network configuration and is not able to forward any ports on the router to internal devices. Which of the following remote access technologies would be BEST suited for this situation?

comments.content: Teamviewer is an awful company and an awful piece of software. Lots of other better options.

discussion.content: Third-party tools is the only option that works without changing any network configuration, like TeamViewer. RDP, VNC, SSH and telnet all require some level of network configuration like opening a port and port forwarding. If you have never used TeamViewer then give it a try as an example.

Virtual network computer is the correct answer. This is an easy one. All other options allow you to configure network settings without needing elevated privileges. VNC is the only option that doesnt give the client administrative privileges.

comments.content: But VNC stands for virtual network computing not computer

Lies.
VNC ports to open are the default ports 5900 and 5800
Not to mention VNC requires port forwarding.

discussion.content: D. Third-party tools such tools include TeamViewer, LogMeIn, and AnyDesk. They establish a connection to a server that both the technician’s and the client’s computers are connected to, which allows the technician to control the client’s computer remotely. These tools often use outbound connections, which can bypass the need for port forwarding or modifying network configurations.

If you connect to your local area network by using a virtual private network (VPN), you don't have to open your PC to the public internet. Instead, when you connect to the VPN, your RD client acts like it's part of the same network and be able to access your PC. There are a number of VPN services available - you can find and use whichever works best for you.

In corporate environments, we use VPNs with remote control technologies, isn't it?
Shouldn't it be Third-party tools?

A would work because you would just need to turn on the Remote Access on the computer, connect to the VPN, and start up an RDC session to gain access. But a third party tool would be so much easier like Anydesk where you have the person install a small piece of software, enter a code, and you're in.
I swear none of these are right? lol surely all protocols will require port forwarding to make a connection to a computer in a different network?
I think it should be VLAN

comments.content: Wouldn't you need to open port 22 for ssh?

discussion.content:
E - Secure shell – enables login to the remote computer via SSH – no changes to the network configuration needed
Not A - RDP - you need port 3389 open – but not allowed to forward any ports on the router to internal devices
Not B – Telnet is not secure
Not C – a “Virtual network computer” requires a VNC server and VNC viewer – we don’t know if there is a VNC setup
Not D – Third-party tools – “not allowed to modify any network configuration”

...doesn't VNC require port forwarding to work remotely?

Whereas third party tools like AnyDesk will establish a connection regardless of network setup?

comments.content: My answer to this is D third-party tools as well.
It is "Performance" in the Task Manager. From "Performance" folder you can open "Resource Monitor". (Windows10)

Shitty corporate American practices
They do it on purpose, I don't understand how this wording game help candidate improve real life problem solving skills?

discussion.content: Hate that they didn't say "Performance Monitor" Still only viable solution.

Selected Answer: D
why are you guys saying task manager? there is no answer that says task manager there is A task scheduler. so that makes it D performance
A is the answer it gives real time memory utilization statistics
Task Manager > Performance tab

discussion.content: Well technically it's Task Manager because that's where the performance tab is.

questions.question_text: A user has reported that a computer is running extremely slow when opening applications. A technician checks the computer and needs to verify memory utilization. Which of the following tools should the technician use to begin troubleshooting the issue?

choices.B: Set the software to save to the %APPDATA% folder
choices.A: Add Ann to the local Power Users group
choices.D: Give Ann write access to C:\Program Files\
choices.C: Add Ann to the local administrator group
choices.E: Give Ann permission to elevate her permissions through a UAC prompt

discussion.content: Set the software to save to the %APPDATA% folder

comments.content: No! Appdata is a globally writeable directory, it is NOT an admin directory. Any user or application can write to Appdata which is why bad actors will sometimes use this directory for malware installation.
However, for this situation the correct solution would be "E" to reconfigure Ann's UAC policy to allow her to provide elevated credentials when needed.

Appdata is a hidden admin folder containing software configuration files. Ann may also need read access to retrieve the file later (aka permanent admin privelages to the folder) so maybe not the best alternative to a one-time UAC prompt.

discussion.content: I say B it is the most secure way to allow the user save her work without giving her admin permissions with UAL or without.

User Account Control makes sure certain changes are made only with approval from the administrator. If the changes are not approved by the administrator, they are not executed, and Windows remains unchanged

comments.content:
With the approval of the user, she gets the administrator permissions, UAC prevents applications executing with elevated permissions without your approval.

In this scenario the user would be able to do ANYTHING UAC would only ask her if you really wanna do this.

questions.question_text:
The IT department has installed new software in the folder C:\Program Files\Business Application\. Ann, a user, runs the business application and tries to save her work. When doing so, Ann receives the following error:
Cannot save file C: \Program Files\Business Application\file1.wrk `" Access is denied.
Which of the following would be the MOST secure solution to this error?
